contentrichtext.text: {{Automatic taxobox | fossil_range = {{Fossil range|Middle Triassic}} | image = Belesodon magnificus.JPG | image_caption = Fossil of ''Chiniquodon theotonicus'' (previously called ''Belesodon magnificus'') in the [[Staatliches Museum für Naturkunde Stuttgart]] | authority = [[Friedrich von Huene|von Huene]], [[1936 in paleontology|1936]] | subdivision_ranks = Species | subdivision = ''C. brasilensis''<br> ''C. kalanoro''<br> ''C. sanjuanensis''<br> ''C. theotonicus'' | synonyms = * ''Belesodon'' <small>von Huene, 1936</small> }} '''''Chiniquodon''''' is a [[genus]] of [[carnivore|carnivorous]] [[cynodont]], which lived during the early [[Late Triassic]] in [[South America]]. ''Chiniquodon'' is closely related to a contemporary genus, ''[[Probelesodon]]'', and close to the ancestry of mammals.<br> Other contemporaries included early [[dinosaur]]s. As both groups filled a similar [[ecological niche]], fairly large therapsid hunters such as ''Chiniquodon'' may have been outcompeted by dinosaurs. ==Species== [[Image:Chinquodon.png |thumb|left| ''Chiniquodon'', UFRGS]] '''''Chiniquodon brasilensis''''' *Place: The [[Paleontological Site Chiniquá]], [[Santa Maria Formation]] *Country: [[Brazil]], in [[geopark]] of [[paleorrota]]. *Age: Carnian, Upper Triassic Remarks: A dog-sized predator, with a skull-length of about 10 cm. This species may not have been formally published. '''''Chiniquodon sanjuanensis'''''<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Ricardo N. Martinez & Catherine A. Forster|date=June 1996|title=The skull of ''Probelesodon sanjuanensis'', sp. nov., from the Late Triassic Ischigualasto Formation of Argentina|journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology|volume=16|issue=2|pages=285–291|url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~db=all~content=a926248101~frm=titlelink|doi=10.1080/02724634.1996.10011315}}</ref> *Place: [[Ischigualasto Formation]] *Country: [[Argentina]] *Age: Carnian (Upper Triassic) This skull was reassigned to this genus in 2002.<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Abdala, F. & Giannini, N. P.|year=2002|title=Chiniquodontid cynodonts: systematic and morphometric considerations |journal=Palaeontology|volume=45|issue=6|pages=1151–1170|doi=10.1111/1475-4983.00280}}</ref> It's differentiated from ''Chiniquodon theotonicus'' because of its [[teeth]] and the shape of the [[Zygomatic_bone#Process|zygomatic process]]. '''''Chiniquodon theotonicus''''' *Place: Santa Maria Formation and [[Chañares Formation]] *Country: Brazil and Argentina *Age: Carnian (Upper Triassic) This species is known from a number of skulls. The [[holotype]] is in the paleontological collection at [[Tübingen]] University, [[Germany]]. '''''Chiniquodon kalanoro'''''<ref>{{Cite journal|author=Christian F. Kammerer; John J. Flynn; Lovasoa Ranivoharimanana; André R. Wyss|year=2010|title=The first record of a probainognathian (Cynodontia: Chiniquodontidae) from the Triassic of Madagascar|journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology|volume=30|issue=6|pages=1889–1894|doi=10.1080/02724634.2010.520784}}</ref> *Place: [[Makay Formation]] *Country: [[Madagascar]] *Age: Ladinian/Carnian (Upper Triassic) This species is known from a [[mandible]] ([[holotype]] UA 10607). ==References== {{Reflist}} * Von Huene. ''Die Fossilien Reptilien des südamerikanischen Gondwanalandes an der Zeitenwende (Denwa-Molteno-Unterkeuper = Ober-Karnisch)''. Ergebnisse der Sauriergrabungen in Südbrasilien 1928/29. (''The fossil reptiles of South American [[Gondwana]] during the temporal transition) (Denwa-Molteno-Upper Triassic = Upper Carnian''). Results of the excavations in South Brazil 1928/29, part II.) 1936. Pages 93–159. {{Fauna and Flora of Paleorrota Geopark}} {{Cynodontia|P.}} [[Category:Cynodonts]] [[Category:Triassic synapsids]] [[Category:Prehistoric synapsids of South America]]
